safety.generalSafety: Generally very safe; essential oil should be used with caution
contraindications: GERD/acid reflux - may worsen symptoms by relaxing lower esophageal sphincter
drugInteractions: May affect absorption of some medications
safety.pregnancyNotes: Tea considered safe in moderate amounts; avoid concentrated essential oil
safety.nursingNotes: May reduce milk supply in large amounts; moderate tea consumption generally safe
safety.childrenNotes: Tea safe for children; avoid essential oil near face of young children

dosage.tea: 1-2 teaspoons dried leaves per cup, steep 5-10 minutes covered, up to 4 cups daily
dosage.capsule: Enteric-coated capsules: 0.2-0.4ml peppermint oil, 2-3 times daily for IBS

content.overview: Peppermint is one of the world's most popular herbs, used for its refreshing flavor and powerful medicinal properties. A natural hybrid of watermint and spearmint, it has been cultivated for centuries as a digestive remedy and cooling refreshment. Its high menthol content gives it distinctive cooling and antispasmodic effects.
content.traditionalUses: Ancient Egyptians, Greeks, and Romans all used mint medicinally. It was strewn on floors for its fresh scent and used to treat digestive complaints. In medieval Europe, it was used to whiten teeth and treat wounds. Traditional Chinese Medicine uses it for headaches, sore throats, and to disperse wind-heat.
content.modernResearch: Clinical trials confirm peppermint's effectiveness for IBS when taken as enteric-coated capsules. Studies show it relaxes smooth muscle in the digestive tract, has antimicrobial effects, and can reduce tension headaches when applied topically. Research supports its use for nausea and indigestion.
content.howToUse: For digestive relief: Drink tea after meals or when symptoms arise. For headaches: Apply diluted essential oil to temples, or drink tea. For congestion: Inhale steam from hot tea or add to steam inhalation. For IBS: Use enteric-coated peppermint oil capsules.
content.harvesting: Harvest leaves just before flowering for highest oil content. Cut stems in mid-morning after dew has dried. Dry quickly in a warm, dark place. Fresh leaves can be used immediately or frozen.
content.cultivation: Perennial that spreads vigorously via runners - consider container planting. Prefers moist, rich soil and partial shade. Regular harvesting encourages bushy growth. Very hardy and easy to grow.
